questions.question_text:
A colleague complains about slow response time on your website.
Examine this query and output:
//IMG//

What is the most likely cause for the high number of lock waits?

choices.D: Your table accesses wait for the operating system level flush.
choices.A: You use the MyISAM storage engine for most common tables.
choices.B: You use the InnoDB storage engine and statements wait while data is inserted.
choices.C: The Innodb Buffer pool is full.

discussion.content: those fields are for MyISAM, so A. There aren't many tables locks with innodb.

comments.content:
There are not locks In MyISAM, because the engine is not supported ACID
Only in Innodb can be locks
I made a mistake. Answer is A

questions.question_text:
Your MySQL installation is running low on space due to binary logs. You need to reduce your log space usage urgently.
Which two sets of actions when completed will accomplish this? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Use SET GLOBAL binlog_expire_logs_seconds=<value> and restart the server.
choices.C: Set binlog_expire_logs_seconds = 0 in my.cnf and restart the server.
choices.F: Use SET GLOBAL binlog_expire_logs_seconds=<value> and run the FLUSH BINARY LOGS command.

discussion.content: EF, the other two don't make sense. You don't to restart the server, and the other just sets a variable but doesn't do anything.

Selected Answer: EF
E and F

Selected Answer: BE
Transactional Support Engine are Innodb and NDB

questions.question_text: Which two storage engines provide a view of the data consistent with the storage system at any moment? (Choose two.)

Examine Joe's account:
CREATE USER 'joe'@'%' IDENTIFIED BY '*secret*'
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON *.* TO 'joe'@'%'
All existing connections for joe are killed.
Which two commands will stop joe establishing access to the MySQL instance? (Choose two.)

choices.E: ALTER USER 'joe'@'%' IDENTIFIED BY '*invalid*' PASSWORD EXPIRE

discussion.content: AE, with C he can still connect.

choices.A: starting and stopping the MySQL instance
choices.E: monitoring the availability of the MySQL instance
choices.D: creating e-mail alerts and SNMP traps for MySQL warnings
choices.B: tracing import and export with mysqidump
choices.G: monitoring of NDB Cluster API nodes
choices.C: deploying the MySQL agent on supported target operating system

questions.question_text:
You have configured MySQL Enterprise Monitor to monitor your MySQL server.
Which four features are available? (Choose four.)

discussion.content:
C, D, E, and F.
Not G. While NDB Cluster support is available in the Enterprise Edition, dedicated monitoring of API nodes is not included in the base MySQL Enterprise Monitor.

Selected Answer: DEFG
NDB API Node Overview: (present only if you are monitoring MySQL NDB Clusters) displays the overview of the NDB API node selected from the All Targets menu. The information displayed relates to the selected node, only.

NDB Data Node Overview: (present only if you are monitoring MySQL NDB Clusters) displays the overview of the NDB Data node selected from the All Targets menu. The information displayed relates to the selected node, only.
